results.title: Our lighthouse adventure
results.creator_credit: Lisa Kebbell and Queenscliff Primary School
results.brief_description:
Created as part of an investigation into the lighthouses of Queenscliff. The Queenscliff Primary School students wanted to write an adventure story in which they were the stars. It was also a way in which they could convey some of the information they had learnt about lighthouses to an audience in an entertaining way.
A photomontage accompanied by commentary from the students on CD ROM.

results.title: British Mutoscope featuring Charlie Chaplin reel
results.brief_description: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope.

constellations_primary.name: Perception, time and flickering images
constellations_primary.description: Using a peep hole and a loop of rotating still images, mutoscopes control the point of view of the audience while also creating the illusion of depth. Filmmakers have since put optical tricks to work creating surreal scenes.

results.description: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope. It was also similar because it didn’t feature projection and only one person could view it at a time. Mutoscope scenes were silent (hence the name) and lasted for one minute. One of the machine’s most famous reels was What the Butler Saw, an early erotic film showing a woman partly undressing as if spied through a keyhole. This reel was so popular that the mutoscope was sometimes known as the ‘What the Butler Saw’ machine.
description_for_label: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope. It was also similar because it didn’t feature projection and only one person could view it at a time. Mutoscope scenes were silent (hence the name) and lasted for one minute. One of the machine’s most famous reels was What the Butler Saw, an early erotic film showing a woman partly undressing as if spied through a keyhole. This reel was so popular that the mutoscope was sometimes known as the ‘What the Butler Saw’ machine.

results.title: Emit
results.brief_description: Emit is a clock brought to life by the Voyager space probe’s final plummet to the surface of a post-apocalyptic, rubbish covered planet not disimilar to our own. Emit stopped at 11:55, as did the rest of the planet. Now he is ticking again, he sets out to find life and discover what makes it tick. But not everything is what it seems.

results.title: Stories from Birchip
results.creator_credit: David Meagher, Dean Lawry, Jason White, Astrid Scott and ACMI Content Development
results.brief_description: Ten stories recorded by ACMI in the Mallee town of Birchip (and one about an Art Deco cinema in nearby Charlton) to celebrate the annual Small Towns summit hosted by Birchip in August 2007. Each film created to be a part of the ACMI MAP (Memory and Place) project is under 7 minutes long and is specifically about relationship to place.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Meagher, Dean Lawry, Jason White, Astrid Scott and ACMI Content Development
results.description: Ten stories recorded by ACMI in the Mallee town of Birchip (and one about an Art Deco cinema in nearby Charlton) to celebrate the annual Small Towns summit hosted by Birchip in August 2007. results.title: The Mallee tree
results.creator_credit: Astrid Scott, David Meagher, Dean Lawry, Jason White and ACMI Content Development
results.brief_description: With its roots deeply set in the earth the humble Mallee finds its strength to face the uncertain challenges of nature. Its tenacity to survive and live on through long droughts and harsh weather conditions is symbolic of the Birchip community who also face similar challenges in their own lives. Written and performed by Glenys Rickard.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Astrid Scott, David Meagher, Dean Lawry, Jason White and ACMI Content Development
